Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation2: The task sits on the critical path for an external delivery promised to a client.
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading my sister’s message: “Don’t forget, you promised to help with the holiday dinner tomorrow. Mom’s counting on you.” My heart squeezed a little. Family gatherings were sacred in our house, and I knew how much it meant to everyone, especially after Dad’s health scare last year. But as I glanced at my laptop, the reality of my other world crashed in. My inbox was full of reminders from my project manager—my part of the client deliverable was due tomorrow, and it was the linchpin for the whole team. If I missed the deadline, the client would be furious, and my colleagues would have to scramble to pick up the pieces. I could almost hear the disappointment in my sister’s voice if I bailed, but I could also picture the frustration on my manager’s face if I let the team down. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I felt torn, wishing I could be in two places at once, knowing I had to choose.
